She will use the loan to buy flour and sugar for her cake making. Her business strategy is to sell cakes to all the shops in her community. She has received 1 previous loan from Kiva's partner, HOPE Congo. She repaid well on her first loan. She hopes to one day be able to start another small business, selling clothes in the market.

loans.use: to pay for flour and sugar.

loans.name: Isidro Danilo

texts.es: Isidro Danilo de 57 años de edad del departamento de chinandega con 5 hijos, se dedica a la actividad de reparacion de calzado (zapatero) , esta solicitando para hacerle mejoras a a su casa de habitacion  como costruir la sala , con el financiamiento comprar material de construccion como:  zinc, arena, cemento, cal, clavos, alambre, entre otros, el brinda las gracias a leon 2000 y el proyecto kiva  por brindarle el apoyo que necesita para mejorar sus condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Isidro Danilo is 57 years old and from the Chinandega department. He has five children and repairs shoes - is a shoemaker - for a living. 

He is requesting a loan in order to make improvements to his home, like building a living room. With this financing he will buy construction materials like zinc sheeting, sand, cement, lime, nails, and wire, among other things. He offers thanks to Fundación León 2000 and Kiva for extending the support he needs to improve the conditions of his life.

loans.use: to buy zinc sheeting, sand, cement, lime, nails, and wire, among other things.

loans.name: Odai

texts.en:
Odai, a 21-year-old single guy, has five brothers and sisters. Odai is a university student majoring in Managerial Information Systems. At the same time, he works to support himself.

Odai has applied for this loan to pay for his summer semester fees.

loans.use: to pay for his summer semester fees.

loans.name: Tharcisse

texts.en:
Tharcisse is married with four children between 14 and 20 years old; all of the children attend school. Tharcisse has been a maize farmer for 8 years; his wife is also a maize farmer. Tharcisse would like a loan to buy more seeds and seed multiplication and to support his labor costs to get the best possible harvest. With the profits, he plans to buy a cow and renovate his house.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more seeds and seed multiplication and support labor costs.

loans.name: Enver

texts.en:
Enver is in his mid-seventies and is married with a grown-up child of his own. For the past ten years, though, he has been taking care of his two nephews, whose parents passed away in a car accident. The nephews were eight and ten years old at the time and they needed care, but Enver was not at a young age to be taking on such a major responsibility. His plan now is to send them to university, and in order to afford their education he needs to expand his business. He has left his business to his nephews in his written will.

Enver is applying for a Kiva loan through VisionFund Albania to purchase insecticides for his vineyards, apple orchards, and vegetables. He has been a VFA client for some time and this is his sixth loan through the institution.

Enver seeks Kiva lenders’ consideration in this matter and thanks everyone in advance for their support.

loans.use: to purchase pesticides.

loans.name: Sylvestre

texts.en:
Sylvestre is married with four children between 1 and 14 years; three of the children attend schools. He has been a maize farmer for 10 years; his wife is also a maize farmer. He needs a loan to buy more seeds and seed multiplication and to pay for support-labor to get the best harvest possible. With the profits, he plans to pay for his children's school fees.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more seeds and seed multiplication and help pay for support-labor costs.

loans.name: Odette

texts.en:
Odette is married and has four children. She has been a maize farmer for 15 years. Her husband works as a businessman. Odette has applied for a loan to buy more seeds and seed multiplication and to help pay for support labor in order to get the best possible harvest. She plans to use the profits to buy cows for rearing.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more seeds and seed multiplication and to help with support-labor costs.

loans.name: Reynas Del Sur Group

texts.es:
EL GRUPO REYNAS DEL SUR ES UN GRUPO, SOLIDARIO CREDITUYO GUADALUPE. ESTA INTEGRADO POR 6 MUJERES SUS NOMBRES SON:
ANABEL,ERIKA,JOSEFINA,LILIANA, MARIA DE LOURDES Y NORA. ELLAS SON AMIGAS Y VECINAS DESDE HACE MAS DE 10 AÑOS, SE ENTIENDEN MUY BIEN ENTRE ELLAS, PORQUE TODAS SON COMERCIANTES Y TODAS QUIEREN SALIR ADELANTE EN SU NEGOCIO.ES POR ESO QUE DECIDIERON FORMAR ESTE GRUPO, PARA SOLICITAR CREDITO Y PODER INVERTIR EN SUS NEGOCIOS.
NORA ES UNA DE LA INTEGRANTES,TIENE 32 AÑOS DE EDAD ES MADRE DE 4 HIJOS DE 17,15,5 Y 3 AÑOS, ELLA VIVE EN UNION LIBRE CON SU PAREJA. 
NORA PIENSA UTILIZAR SU CREDITO,EN SURTIR MAS MERCANCIA ROPA DE TEMPORADA, COSMETICOS Y BISUTERIA.
NORA A FUTURO, LE GUSTARIA TENER UNA BOUTIQUE GRANDE CON VENTA DE ROPA PARA DAMA Y ACCSESORIOS, YA QUE EN ESTE MOMENTO ELLA VENDE EN LOS MERCADOS RODANTES. ELLA QUIERE LLEGAR A SER UNA GRAN EMPRESARIA PARA QUE SUS HIJOS TENGAN UNA VIDA FELIZ SIN PRIVACIONES DE NINGUN TIPO.
texts.en:
The communal bank "Reynas del Sur" is a group that is working with Credituyo in Guadalupe.  The group has 6 members who are all women, and their names are: Anabel, Erika, Josefina, Liliana, Maria de Lourdes, and Nora.  They have been friends and neighbors for more than 10 years, and they understand each other very well because they are all merchants who want to make progress with their respective businesses.  The reason that they formed this group is so that they could request loans that would enable them to invest in their businesses.

Nora is one of the members.  She is 32 years old, and is the mother of 4 children aged 17, 15, 5 and 3.  She is in a common-law marriage with her partner.

Nora plans to use this loan to stock up with merchandise, including seasonal clothing, cosmetics and accessories.  In the future, Nora would like to have a big store where she could sell women's clothing and accessories, because right now she is selling in the traveling markets.  She wants to become a great businesswoman so that her children will have a happy life without any kind of hardship.

loans.use: to stock up with merchandise to increase her inventory of clothing.

loans.name: Ana Suheildy

texts.es: Ana Suheidy del municipo de chinandega, tiene por actividad ecomomica el negocio de meracaderia en general, y caramanchel,( venta de cosmeticos, y productos de pulperia) desde hace 5 años el cual lo tiene ubicado en su casa de habitacion , esta emprendedora inicio dicha actividad por la necesidad de tener una herramienta de trabajo para ayudar con los gastos de sus hijos, en la actualidad ha demostrado que es una persona responsable, trabajadora,  con ganas de superacion, con solvencia de pagos, Ana ya ha tenido creditos con fundacion leon 2000 lo cual le ha servido para hacer crecer el mismo dando buena atencion  a sus clientos con los productos que distribuye, Ana esta solicitando el fianciamiento para invertir en la compra de cosmeticos como: rubor, lapiz labial, base, lapiz de ojos, cremas antiarrugas, sombras, corrector,  rimel, entre otros.
texts.en:
Ana Suheidy from the municipality of Chinandega has a store where for 5 years she has sold general merchandise, including cosmetics and groceries. It is located in her residence. This enterprising woman began her store due to the necessity to have a means of supporting her children. 

She has now demonstrated that she is a responsable hard-working person who wishes to get ahead and meet her obligations. Ana has already had loans through Fundacion Leon 2000, which has helped her satisfy customers with products she sells. Ana is requesting financing to purchase cosmetics such as blush, lip pencils, base, eye pencils, antiwrinkle creams, eye shadow, correcting make up, and mascara, among other items to sell.

loans.use: buy blush, lip pencils, base, eye pencils, antiwrinkle cream, eye shadow, correcting make up, and mascara, among other items to sell.

loans.name: Thelma Olimpia

texts.es: Thelma continúa con su negocio de video juego, negocio pequeño pero rentable, cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo quien labora como conductor, y su hijo que administra el negocio. Thelma necesita mejorar su techo, ya que es de Nicalit por sus años, se ha quebrado, y con las fuertes lluvias se le pasa el agua, lo que cambiara techo con este nuevo préstamo comprando: laminas de zinc, cuartones de madera, clavo para hacer el cambio y mejorar esta condición y bienestar para su familia.
texts.en: Thelma continues her video game business, a small but profitable business. She has the support of her husband who works as a driver and that of her son who manages the business. Thelma needs to improve her roof as it's made of Nicalit. Due to its age it has broken and when there are heavy rains, water passes through it. With this new loan she will change her roof, buying zinc sheets, wooden beams, and nails to make the change and improve its condition and the well-being of her family.

loans.use: to buy zinc sheets, beams, and nails to repair the roof.

loans.name: Nana

texts.en:
Nana is 33 years old. She is married and lives in the Vale district with her family: husband, Zaza; three children (5, 11 and 12 years old) and mother-in-law, who is a pensioner. The older children go to the local [school]. Nana and her husband run an agricultural business. In particular, they have three milk cows and a calf. They produce dairy food: cheese, curds and yogurt, and sell them at the local open market. The family owns 0.75 hectares of land as well, where they grow potatos and cabbage. Nana and Zaza work hard during the spring and summer seasons to get a good harvest. Along with their agricultural business, they are also busy with trading. Seasonally, they sell vegetables and fruits using their own Ford Transit car in nearby villages. The total average monthly income of the family is 1000 lari.

Nana requested a loan for cultivation of the agricultural land and to purchase additional agricultural products to sell. After properly doing the seasonal work, she hopes to get a good harvest. Nana and Zaza will sell their harvested products together with other agricultural products in the nearby villages. They hope to get their planned income. With increased income, they will be able to spend more on the family’s daily needs. As a result, the family’s living conditions will improve.

loans.use: to water agricultural land and purchase agricultural products for selling

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es: Carmen, de 73 años de edad , soltera , sin hijos del municipio de chinandega, esta emprendedora es una persona, capaz, luchadora, ,que todavia a su edad , lucha dia a dia por tener mejores condiciones de vida,  Carmen tiene por actividad economica la venta de productos varios   el tiempo de tener el negocio 41 años el la actualidad a pesar de las dificultades propias como el tiempo, problemas ecomonicos, la edad ha superado las pruebas , gracias al apoyo que  leon 2000 junto al programa kiva le ha brindado para sacar adelante su negocio, invirtiendo en productos el cual ofreces a su clientelas. Los productos que ofrece son: pocicles,  golosinas, galletas, gelatinas, sopas maruchan.
texts.en: Carmen, who is 73 years old, is single and has no children. She comes from the town of Chinandega. This entrepreneur is a capable, hard-working person, who still, at her age, works day after day to have better living conditions. Carmen's business is the sale of a variety of products. She has had this business for 41 years. Now, in spite of her difficulties, such as the weather, economic problems, and her age, she has overcome these trials, thanks to the support that Leon 2000 together with the Kiva program have offered her so that she can advance her business by investing in the products that she offers her customers. The products that she offers are popsicles, candies, cookies, jellies, and Maruchan soups.

loans.use: to buy popsicles, candies, cookies, jellies, and Maruchan soups to sell

loans.name: Juana De La Concepcion

texts.es: Juana, de 62 años de edad, soltera con dos hijos, esta emprendedora siempre se ha caracterizado por ser trabajadora, responsable, con animo de superacion, ya que ha demostrado que con su esfuerzo pudo sacar adelante a sus hijos a pesar de los problemas de salud de uno de ellos ya que hasta la fecha la envia a la escuela especial , ha sido  la razon por la cual la motiva dia a dia a levantarse temprano para seguir luchando por ellos,  Juana  tiene por actividad economica la una pulperia ubicada  en su casa de habitacion, tiene  de experiencia en el negocio 22 años, el financiamiento lo quiere para comprar productos de consumo diario para el hogar como:  leche, pan, arroz, azucar, cosmeticos, ropa, queso, frijoles, verduras, tiste entre otros
texts.en:
Juana, 62 years old, is single with two children. She is an enterprising woman who has always been characterized as being hard-working, responsible, and motivated to succeed. She has demonstrated that with effort, she was able to move her children forward despite one's health problems who is currently going to a special school. This is the reason she is motivated to get up early every day to continue fighting for them.

Juana works at a small store located in her home and has 22 years experience in this business. She would like this loan to buy everyday consumer products such as milk, bread, sugar, cosmetics, clothes, cheese, beans, vegetables, tiste (a traditional drink), and other items.

loans.use: to buy milk, bread, rice, sugar, cosmetics, clothes, cheese, beans, vegetables, tiste (a traditional drink), and other items

loans.name: Dossou

texts.fr: Dossou est un homme marié de 36 ans. Père de 2 enfants âgés de 2 et 5 ans dont 01 scolarisé, il gagne sa vie en exerçant comme commerçant dans l’achat et la revente d’appareil de sonorisation. Servant une catégorie très variée de clientèle, il rêve d’avoir une boutique et de pouvoir employer des jeunes aspirants à son domaine d’activité. Il effectue ses opérations financières depuis cette année avec WAGES et sollicite un crédit en vue de s’approvisionner en appareils de sonorisation variés.  Il espère prendre son envol avec ce crédit et participer activement à l’épanouissement de ses enfants. Il est dans cette activité il y a 05ans.
texts.en: Dosou is a 36-year old married man. He has two children, two and five years of age, one of whom is in school. He earns a living as a vendor, buying and reselling audio electronics.  Serving a very wide public, he dreams of having a store and being able to employ young trainees. Since this year, he manages his financial transaction with WAGES. He is seeking a loan in order to stock up on audio electronics. He hopes for his business to take off so that he would be able to  ensure his children's well-being. He has been in this business for five years.

loans.use: to buy audio electronics.

loans.name: Martha Elena

texts.es: Martha Elena de 50 años de edad del municipio de chinanadega, con tres hijos, este emprendedor tiene por actividad economica la venta de productos varios como (gaseosas, hot dog, granos, golosinas, entre otros.) la actividad que la inicio desde hace 10 años para la ayudar con los gastos del hogar, el negocio lo tiene ubicado en su casa de habitacion. En la actulidad ha salido ha delante con el apoyo que fundacion leon 2000 le ha brindado y con el programa kiva ya que le ha permitido invertir y suertir su pequeño negocio el cual le genera ganacia para el sustento de su familia.
texts.en: Martha Elena, who is 50 years old, is from the town of Chinandega. She has three children. This entrepreneur's business is selling a variety of products such as soft drinks, hot dogs, grains, candies, and other items. She began this business 10 years ago to help with the household expenses. The business is located in her home. Now she has moved forward with the help that the Foundation Leon 2000, together with the Kiva program, has offered her, since it has allowed her to invest and stock her little business, which generates earnings for the support of her family.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks, hot dogs, grains, candies, and other items to sell

loans.name: Immaculee

texts.en:
Immaculee is married and has three children. Her husband works as a cobbler. She has been a maize farmer for 7 years. She wants this loan to buy more seeds, for seed multiplication [production of seeds for sale or for future planting] and to pay for labor costs to get the best harvest. She wants to use the profits for renovating her house.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy and harvest seeds and to pay for labor costs.

loans.name: Claudia Cristina

texts.es:
Claudia es una mujer de 37 años, se encuentra felizmente casada, vive en la ciudad de Nazca con su esposo y sus 3 hijos, ella es una persona muy alegre, entusiasta y trabajadora, que dedica todos sus esfuerzos para que junto con su esposo puedan sacar adelante a su familia; lamentablemente desde muy joven tuvo que trabajar para solventar sus gastos y apoyar a sus padres, por ello no pudo terminar de cursar sus estudios primarios, pero Claudia sueña con poder hacerlo algún día; en sus ratos libres le gusta ver televisión en compañía de sus hijos y en algunas ocasiones cocina un riquísimo Seco de Res para compartir con su familia.
Por iniciativa propia y gracias al apoyo de su familia, desde hace varios años Claudia puso en marcha su pequeño negocio de venta de anticuchos, ella realiza su labor de manera ambulatoria, desde tempranas horas de la mañana empieza a elaborar los diversos platos para que en las noches cuando inicie sus ventas todo esté listo y sus clientes puedan degustar los riquísimos anticuchos, tripitas, pancita, bofe, entre otros; Claudia se siente a gusto en su trabaja y cree que su negocio marcha bien debido  a que sus cliente la recomiendan por su excelente sazón y buena atención.
Claudia se encuentra muy agradecida con los prestatarios Kiva, ya que gracias a la ayuda brindada podrá realizar la construcción de su vivienda hecha de adobes, ya que actualmente su casita está hecha de esteras; de esta manera Claudia podrá contar con una vivienda en mejores condiciones, brindando seguridad y bienestar para su familia, y así en un futuro no muy lejano espera poder tener un restaurant propio para seguir creciendo y saliendo con su familia.
texts.en:
Claudia is a 37-year-old woman who is happily married and lives in the city of Nazca with her husband and their three children. She is a very happy, enthusiastic, and hardworking person who devotes all her effort, along with that of her husband, to getting their family ahead. Regrettably, from a very young age she had to work to settle her expenses and support her parents. For this reason she couldn't complete her elementary school studies. Still, Claudia dreams about being able to do this one day. In her free time she likes to watch TV with her children and on occasion she cooks the delicious dish, Seco de Res (Cilantro Beef Stew), to share with her family.

By her own initiative and thanks to the support of her family, Claudia began her small business selling kebabs several years ago. She performs her work as a street vendor. From the early morning hours she begins to prepare the diverse dishes so that when she begins her sales in the evenings, everything is ready and her customers can taste her delicious kebabs, intestines, tripe, and cow lungs, among other items. Claudia feels happy with her work and believes that her business is going well due to her customers recommending her for her food's excellent flavor and her good service.

Claudia is very thankful along with Kiva borrowers since thanks to the help given she will be able to carry out the construction of her home made of adobe. Currently her small home is made of mats. In this way Claudia will be able to have a home that's in better condition, giving safety and comfort to her family. In the not-too-distant future she hopes to be able to have her own restaurant to continue growing and going out with her family.

loans.use: to build her home.

loans.name: Inés

texts.es:
Doña Inés, comerciante, dueña de su propio negocio es una pulpería, con 19 años de experiencia, su negocio consiste en vender produtos de alimento y uso personal tales como de arroz americano y nacional, azúcar, aceite, frijoles, nevax, golosinas, purina, pollo, cerdo, entre otros. Se ubica a orilla de la carretera que queda cerca de su casa, y les vende a las personas que viajan y pasan diariamente por esa zona, tambien sus mismo vecinos que viven en el sector, ella no deja de vender y tiene una ventaja que no tiene competencia por eso es que siempre le va bien en su negocio. Reside en el departamento de Masaya, su núcleo familiar es de 3 ella y sus dos hijos. 

Necesita invertirle a la pulpería y  se acerca a nuestra oficinas Ceprodel para solicitar un nuevo financiamiento en el que pueda suministrarle mas a su negocio y que le ayude con la demanda que es muy fuerte. Gracias a los créditos que ha obtenido por parte de Ceprodel a engrandecido mas su negocio y mejorado su calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Ines, a merchant, has owned a small grocery store for 19 years. Her business consists of selling food and personal products like imported and local rice, sugar, oil, beans, toilet paper, pet food, chicken, beef and other things. The store is located on the edge of the highway close to her home and she sells to people who travel through this area and pass by daily, as well as to her neighbors. She never stops selling and doesn't have any competition, which is why her business is going well. She lives in the state of Masaya. Her family is comprised of herself and her two children.

She needs to invest in the store and came to the Ceprodel offices to ask for a new loan to stock her store better and meet her high demend. Thanks to the loans from Ceprodel she has grown her business and improved her quality of life.

loans.use: to buy imported and local rice, sugar, oil, beans, toilet paper, snacks, pet food, chicken, pork, etc.

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene is a single mother of three children ages 10 to 18 years. She describes herself as a determined woman. 

Irene operates a grocery store where she sells vegetables and fruits such as bananas, avocados, watermelon and pineapple. She has been involved in this business for 15 years. Her business is located in a viable area and her primary customers are local residents. Irene describes her biggest business challenge to be the fruit spoiling, especially during the cold season when fewer customers buy. Her business goal is to expand her business within 5 years.

Irene plans to use the KES5,800 loan to buy a solar lantern for use as a light in her house in order to reduce the cost of paraffin.

loans.use: to buy a solar lantern for her home.

loans.name: Jorge Alberto

texts.es: Jorge  Alberto  de 57 años de edad, casado  tiene por actividad ecomomica la venta de productos lacteos, tiene 8 años de experiencia en el negocio, el cual lo distribuye de forma ambulante,  actividad ecomomica que inicio  con un poco de ingresos propio como obrero  y lo aprendio de la esposa , hoy en dia ha  crecido en demanda ya que tiene mucha cliente y ofrece varidad y calidad de productos, el fiananciamiento lo quiere para invertir en productos lacteos como: leche, queso, cuajada la cual la vende  pro libra. En la actualidad da gracias a leon 2000 y programa kiva por la ayuda que le brindan con los financiamiento para poder trabajar y sacar adelante a su familia y mejorar sus condiciones de vida.
texts.en: Jorge Alberto is 57 years old, married, and sells dairy products for work. He has eight years of experience in the business, and distributes as a street vendor. He began this work with his small income as a worker and learned it from his wife. Today his demand has increased as he has many customers and offers a variety of quality products. He wants the funding to invest in dairy products like milk, cheese, and curd, which he sells by the pound. At present he is thankful for Leon 2000 and the Kiva program for the help they are giving him with the funding in order to be able to work, get his family ahead, and improve their lifestyle.

loans.use: to buy dairy products like milk, cheese, and curd.

loans.name: Juan Jesus

texts.es: El señor Juan  es  una persona  responsable  y  muy  trabajadora, a lo largo de sus créditos se  ha  distinguido por  tener  una excelente  cultura  de pagos   es por ello que  nuevamente  se  acerca  a la institución para  que  lo apoyemos  en  el proyecto  de  remodelación de vivienda  ,  el desea    terminar la  construcción del portal de  su  casa, ve  en  el crédito la posibilidad  de  que su  hogar  tenga  una mejor  imagen por  lo que  se  encuentra  muy  contento ya  que  este  es  el patrimonio de   sus  hijos.
texts.en: Juan is responsible and hardworking. Through the course of his loans he has distinguished himself by having an excellent payment ethic, which is why he came again to the institution for support in remodeling his home. He wants to finish constructing an entryway for his house. He sees in this loan the possibility of his home having a better image, which would make him happy because it is his children's inheritance.

loans.use: to construct an entry way for his home.

loans.name: Ineza

texts.en:
Ineza is from Badiauri village of Sagarejo District. She is 30 years old, married and lives with her family: husband – Gocha and parents-in-law, who are pensioners. Gocha is a chief cook and gets a salary every month. Her mother-in-law also works, at the village school. Ineza and her father in-law are busy with agricultural activities. They have two milking cows and produce cheese. Part of the cheese is used by the family and the rest is sold locally. The family also owns a vineyard. They work hard during spring and summer seasons to get a good harvest. They pick grapes in autumn, part of which is used for production of wine. They sell the rest of grapes and the wine they have produced in nearby villages. Total average monthly income of the family is 1000 Lari.

Ineza requested a loan for purchasing piglets. She will raise them and sell them in winter. Grown pigs will be sold for a good price. By doing this, she will be able to expand her agricultural business and increase the income of the family accordingly. With the increased income she will be able to improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to purchase piglets to raise and sell.

loans.name: Maia

texts.en:
Maia is 34 years old; she lives in a small village of Sagarejo District with her family: husband – Mamuka and her brother-in-law. Mamuka is a construction worker and gets service fees for work. He also helps Maia and his brother in the family agricultural business. In particular, they have 3 milk cows and produce cheese. The cheese trader buys most of their cheese. Along with their small dairy farm they are busy with a plot. They own 1 hectare of land, where wheat is grown. Total average monthly income of the family is 1000 Lari.

Maia requested a loan for purchasing wheat. With more wheat she will be able to feed more cattle. This will increase the sales from her business and positively affect the income of the family. With the increased income she will be able to reinvest in the family agricultural business to expand it and make more profitable. As a result of the above mentioned activities the living conditions of the family will be improved.

loans.use: to purchase wheat to feed the cattle.

loans.name: Ridvan

texts.en:
Ridvan is a 44-year-old married man with six children, all girls, ranging in age from four to fifteen years old. The family lives in a village in the southeastern part of the country. 

For the past six years, Ridvan has been running a dairy and animal sale business that has proved to be profitable, and the growth in clientele has been proving that there is high demand for what he offers.

Redvan has requested a Kiva loan via VisionFund Albania in order to purchase more cows to help his business grow. This is his third loan with the previous ones being successfully paid off. 

With any profits he makes from the growth of his business, he will be able to raise and educate his children and re-invest in his business. This loan will be a tremendous help to him and his family and they are all very grateful to Kiva potential lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more cows.

loans.name: Redgernold

texts.en:
Redgernold lives in Malindi, Kenya. He is married and has two children – one is in school. He is a farmer and began farming two years ago. Besides farming, Redgernold is also employed as a teacher at a private primary school.

Redgernold learnt of Milango from his friends and he is now applying for a loan of 21,100 Kenyan shillings to pay for pesticides and fertilizers. The only challenge he faces is the seasonal weather. Redgernold’s future ambition is to be able to farm an acreage of about ten acres. He will save his extra income to pay for his children’s school fees.

loans.use: to pay for pesticides and fertilizers.

loans.name: Neli

texts.en:
Neli is 47 years old. She is married and lives in a small village in Sagarejo District with her family: husband – Guram and their 27 year-old son. The family earns their living through agricultural activities. They have 2 milk cows and a calf. They produce dairy food: cheese, curds and yogurt and sell them on the local open market. 

Along with agricultural activities, Neli and her son are agricultural workers. They help neighbor farmers and get service fees for their work. They work hard but their income is hardly enough for food and everyday expenses for the three-member family. The total average monthly income of the family is 700 Lari.

Neli requested a loan for purchasing an additional milk cow. This will help her expand her dairy farm. Neli will be able to produce more dairy food and since there is a great demand for her products at the market, she will sell them for a good price. This will increase the family income accordingly and she will be able to improve the family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase a cow.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is 32 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with two children. 

Sarah is selling coconuts and green bananas in her local community. She has had this business for six years. Aside from that, she also has a sari-sari (variety) store that sells canned goods, snacks and beverages. 

She requested a loan for 5,000 Philippines pesos to buy stock of coconut and green bananas to resell.

Sarah has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Sarah hopes to improve her business for the education of her children.

loans.use: to buy stock of coconuts and green bananas to resell.

loans.name: Zakaria

texts.en:
Zakaria is a resident of Changamwe, Kenya. He runs a retail shop which has been in operation for six months. His business is located in the area normally visited by truck drivers linking the two Kenyan cities. He is married. Zakaria received the startup capital for his shop from his savings and mainly sells cereals.

Zakaria joined Milango upon introduction by his friends and is applying for a loan of 31,450 Kenyan shillings to purchase additional stock of cereals. The only challenge in the business has been the high cost of retail stock and price fluctuations, but Zakaria believes this will be sorted since the harvesting season just began. Zakaria believes the business will grow and he will soon have a chain of businesses and increase his profits.

loans.use: buy cereals to sell

loans.name: Irfan

texts.en:
Irfan is in his fifties, married and has two children, twenty-six and twenty-four years old. He and his family live in a little town in the south of Albania. For the past five years, he has been carrying out a bar-café business. 

Irfan's business has been doing fine and he wants to grow it now by offering more items and services.  For this, he needs to buy more inventory. The money he has at the moment is almost nothing and cannot be used for this purpose because he has been the only one to financially support his family of five.

Irfan is applying for a Kiva loan now through VisionFund Albania to stock up on inventory items.  This will be his third loan, with the previous ones being repaid.  The previous loans have not been Kiva loans and he very much wants to thank in advance all lenders at Kiva for their great support in this matter.

loans.use: stock his cafe/bar

loans.name: Rukia

texts.en:
Rukia is a married mother of three school-going children. She lives in Mombasa, Kenya. She owns a salon which has been in operation for the last six years. She started it off from her savings and an investment from her parents. This is her only source of income.

Rukia has seen the business grow and when she heard of Milango from her friends, she decided to join in order to access credit. Her challenge has been the lack of adequate equipment, an issue she believes can be sorted by this loan.

Rukia is asking for a loan of 41,850 Kenyan shillings to purchase a dryer, mirrors, chairs and cosmetics for her business. She will use the extra income from this loan will help improve the living standards of her family.

loans.use: buy a dryer, mirrors, chairs and cosmetics

loans.name: La Lumiere 2 Group

texts.en:
Yannick, aged 38, is a single mother with a 15-year-old child. She also provides for her father. Yannick is representing the La Lumiere 2 group. She owns a small restaurant. She has been operating this business for over 15 years. She will use the loan to buy chicken, fish, oil, and charcoal. Her business strategy is to offer good customer service. She is friendly and welcoming to all of her customers. 

Yannick has received 1 previous loan from Kiva's partner, HOPE Congo. She has a good repayment record. She dreams of opening a shop and traveling abroad.  She hopes her daughter will be able to study abroad after she graduates from high school. She will provide what she can to help her daughter.

loans.use: buy food and charcoal for her restaurant

loans.name: Elida

texts.en:
Elida is 37 years old and is living with her husband and 2 sons. Her house is equipped only with running water. It is located in Nueva Arica, in the province of Chiclayo in Northern Peru. She is a hard-working woman determined to progress and improve her living conditions and that of her family. As a result, she has a strategic mind.  This is now the second loan she is taking with Edpyme Alternativa with the support of Kiva, given that the first one was successfully and punctually repaid.

The primary business activities in the region are agriculture, farming, and tourism. Elida raises and sells livestock, mainly poultry, turkeys, ducks, and guinea pigs. The corrals where the livestock are kept are located in the rear section of her property. She feeds them a balanced diet and natural plants (alfalfa). When the livestock have reached an optimum size and weight she sells them at the different markets in the city of Chiclayo. 

After her first loan helped her to consolidate her business, Elida is now requesting a loan of 1500 nuevos soles to make updates to her house and improve the quality of the condition where her family lives. She has proven a very responsible person.

loans.use: improve her house

loans.name: Bienvenida

texts.en:
Bienvenida is a resident of Talibon, Bohol. She is 47 years old and has a business selling home-cooked snacks. For 22 years now, she sells pancake and rice cake in the neighborhood. Bienvenida would like to increase her production and is asking for a loan to buy flour, sugar and cooking oil.

Bienvenida has five children. Her eldest is 24 years old and her youngest is 16 years old. Once her business is doing good, Bienvenida will be able to provide her family with the basic necessities like a healthy diet and pay for household bills.

loans.use: buy flour, sugar and cooking oil

loans.name: Kokovi

texts.fr: Kokovi  est une femme veuve âgée de 41 ans avec 1 enfant de 14 ans qui est scolarisé. Elle prend de sa progéniture et d’elle-même en effectuant le commerce du charbon de bois. Confrontée à un problème de liquidité, il lui est difficile de pouvoir disposer à tout moment de stock suffisant pour pouvoir couvrir la demande. Elle fait confiance à WAGES et y épargne ses revenus. Elle sollicite un crédit dans le but de s’approvisionner en stock de marchandises. Elle espère que ce crédit lui permettra d’améliorer ses rendements et enfin de prendre soin de sa progéniture.
texts.en:
Kokovi is a 41-year-old widow with a 14-year-old child, who is in school. She supports her offspring and herself through commerce in charcoal. Confronted with a liquidity problem, it is difficult for her to have a sufficient inventory at all times, so as to meet the demand. 

She trusts the microfinance institution WAGES and saves her revenues there. She is requesting a loan with the goal of stocking up  on products. She hopes that this loan will enable her to improve her returns and finally to take care of her child.

loans.use: to buy charcoal

loans.name: Ra's Group

texts.en:
Ra, 33, is a married father of one son who is still in his care.  They are living in a village in the Ek Phnom district of Battambang province, Cambodia. He has been a rice farmer and fisherman for eighteen years. To earn extra income, his wife has been planting watermelons and beans to support the family. They can earn around KHR 73,900 per day from their current businesses.

This is Ra’s first loan with VisionFund, while his group member has been with VisionFund for two cycles already. As the group leader, Ra is leading this group to apply for a loan with VisionFund of KHR 1,000,000 each. He will use his portion to buy fertilizers and an aspirating pipe for using with a water pump. He hopes this loan will enable his family to make more income to make their living better.

loans.use: buy fertilizer and a pipe

loans.name: Sinang's Group

texts.en:
Sinang is twenty-seven years old and lives in the Ek Phnom district of Cambodia. She has three children, two daughters and one son, one of whom is a dependent working in the family's business. 

To make a living, Sinang has been planting rice and watermelons for ten years, while her husband is fisherman. Sinang earns approximately KHR 60,000 per day from her current business and spends KHR 44,700 to support her family. The main challenge for her is lack of water for her rice field.

This is Sinang’s first group loan. Her group consists of two female members. She is leading her group to apply for a loan of KHR 1,000,000 each. As the group leader, Sinang is going to use her portion to buy a boat for her family's business. She hopes to make more income to support her family and make their living better.

loans.use: buy a fishing boat

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is 56 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with six children. 

Susan is selling fish in her local community. She has had this business for eight years. She requested a loan for 5,000 Philippines pesos to buy more fish to resell, like milk fish, sardines and flying fish.

Susan has been a member of HSPFI since 2012. In the future, Susan hopes to improve her business for the education of her children.

loans.use: to buy a variety of fish to resell.

loans.name: Thorn's Group

texts.en:
Thorn is aged 29. She is married and blessed with three children, two daughters and one son. She lives in a rural village of the Mongkul Borey district in Cambodia. To earn a living, she has been involved in rice farming and grocery selling for 10 years. She supplements her family’s income by working as a paid worker. Thorn is able to earn around KHR10,000 per day from her current business. The main challenge for her is low crop yields from crops that have been destroyed by floods.

Thorn has been with VisionFund for two loan cycles, while her fellow group member has been with VisionFund for four cycles. She has used the past loans successfully to make her family's living conditions better. Now she is leading her group of two to apply for a loan with VisionFund of KHR 1,200,000 each. As the group leader, she is going to use her portion to buy fertilizers and grocery items for resale. With this loan, she hopes to get more income from her business for supporting the family for a better life.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and grocery items.

location.town: Banteay Meanchey Province, Mongkul Borey District

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina is a 60-year-old married woman with three grown-up children. The oldest child is 30 years old. Rosalina's husband works as a farmer.

Rosalina tills their rice field in San Jose, Talibon, Bohol, Philippines. Rosalina has been growing rice for six years. This business provides them the income that they need.

This loan will be used to purchase rice seedlings and fertilizers and pay  for the maintenance of the equipment used in the field, such as tractors and others. In the coming days, Rosalina hopes to further improve their yield by applying methods that could enhance the productivity of their farm, thus giving them a higher income. Any additional income she adds will be saved for future needs.

loans.use: to buy rice seedlings and fertilizer and pay for maintenance for the equipment (a tractor and other items).

loans.name: Phoeurt's Group

texts.en:
Living in a rural area of the Mongkul Borey of Banteay Meanchey province, Phoeurt is married with four children, three of whom (two daughters and one son) are working as paid workers in Thailand. She has been in the pig raising business for fifteen years while her husband is a paid worker in a local area. With the family's current business, she is able to earn about KHR 20,000 per day to support her family.

Phoeurt's group consists of three members. She and another member have been with VisionFund for five cycles while the other has been with VisionFund for four cycles. She completely paid back the past loans, which have helped her make a better living. Now leading her group to apply for a loan with VisionFund, Phoeurt, who is the leader, is going to use her portion to buy 2 more piglets and pig feed. She hopes this loan will enable her to increase her family's income to improve her lifestyle.

loans.use: To buy pigs and pig feed

location.town: Banteay Meanchey Province, Mongkul Borey District

loans.name: Sokha's Group

texts.en:
Sokha, aged 52, is a married father living in a rural area of the Ek Phnom district of Battambang province, Cambodia. He has eight children, four of whom are still in his care. Sokha has been rice farming on one-hectare of farmland for twenty five years.  He also supplements his family’s income by fishing. He can earn around KHR43,300 per day to support his family. The main challenge for his business is lack of water for his rice farming. 

Sokha’s group consists of two members. He has been with VisionFund for one cycle and has successfully paid back the past loan. The other member has been with VisionFund for two cycles. In order to support his family for a better living, Sokha is leading his group to apply for a loan with VisionFund. As the leader, he is going to use his portion of KHR 1,200,000 to buy fertilizers for his farmland and a water pump and use a portion of it to fix his boat. He hopes this loan will enable him to increase his family's income and also improve their standard of living.

loans.use: buy fertilizer and a water pump

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie is 41 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with one child.
 
Tessie is selling snacks in her local community, like "suman" and "biko" (rice-based desserts). She has had this business for seven years. She requested a loan for 4,000 Philippines pesos to buy raw ingredients for making these snacks, like sugar, cheese, flour and margarine.

Tessie has been a member of HSPFI since 2012. In the future,Tessie hopes to improve her business for the education of her child.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients for making snacks.

loans.name: Noussi Eugénie

texts.fr: Mariée et mère de deux enfants qui vont tous à l'école, Noussi Eugénie a une boutique où elle vend des mèches, des tissages et des gels depuis quelques années. Elle se ravitaille à l'extérieur du Bénin. Face à la forte demande de ses clients qui augmente sans cesse grâce au bon emplacement du fonds de commerce, elle a sollicité et a obtenu un micro crédit auprès de Finadev en vue de de combler les attentes de ses clients et de maximiser son profit. Le surplus généré lui permettra de participer à la scolarisation des enfants et d'épargner. Elle ambitionne ouvrir un grand salon de coiffure et de mèche.
texts.en:
Married and a mother of two children, who both go to school, Noussi Eugénie has a store where she has been selling hair extensions, weaves, and gels for a few years. She stocks up from outside Benin. 

In face of the strong demand from her customer base, which is ever-growing thanks to the right use of capital, she requested and obtained a micro-loan from Finadev with the aim of fulfilling the expectations of her customers and to maximize her profit. 

The surplus generated will enable her to help cover her children's school costs and to save money. Her ambition is to open a large salon for hairstyling and hair extensions.

loans.use: to buy 2 packets of hair extensions, 3 packets of weaves, 2 containers of gel, and a 100-gram container of hair product

loans.name: Hing's Group

texts.en:
Hing is 38 years old. She lives in a rural village of the Mongkul Borey district of Banteay Meanchey province, Cambodia. She has four children, three of whom (two daughters and one son) are still dependent on her. To earn a living, she has worked as a rice farmer on 2 hectares of farmland for 15 years. She earns approximately KHR19,000 per day to spend on family's basic needs.

Hing has been with VisionFund for two loan cycles and completely repaid the past loans; her fellow group member has been with VisionFund for one cycle. The past loans have helped her to make a better living. As the group leader, she is going to use her portion to buy fertilizers for her farmland. With this loan, she hopes to increase her crop yields so as to earn more income to set aside some money to afford to buy a hand tractor for her rice farming.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for her farmland.

location.town: Banteay Meanchey Province, Mongkul Borey District

loans.name: Sinat's Group

texts.en:
Sinat is 40 years old and is living in a rural village in the Mongkul Borey district in Cambodia. She has three children, one daughter and two sons. Sinat is a rice farmer, and her husband is a sculptor. She has been in this business for ten years, earning approximately KHR30,000 per day. She spends KHR15,000 to meet her family’s need. 

Sinat has received four loans and successfully paid back the past loans with VisionFund while the other member of her group has been with VisionFund for two cycles. After receiving the loans from VisionFund, she is confident that she will be able to make her living better. She is leading her group of two to apply for a loan with VisionFund of KHR1,000,000 each. As the group leader, she is going to use her portion to buy fertilizers and a portion of it to buy more sculptured items for her husband's business. She hopes to make more income from her current business so as to improve her lifestyle.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and more sculptured items

location.town: Banteay Meanchey Province, Mongkul Borey District

loans.name: Khenh

texts.en:
Khenh is requesting a new loan to buy a greater range and quantity of products to restock her general store. This purchase will help her to better meet the needs of her customers. Her previous loan enabled her to improve her business and offer her customers a greater variety of products. 

She hopes that her new loan will assist her in increasing the size of her store and increase sales, and will also help her to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to stock her general store with a greater range and quantity of products.

loans.name: Kai's Group

texts.en:
Kai, aged 31, lives in a rural area of the Sangke district of Battambang province, Cambodia. He and his wife have no children yet. Kai has been planting rice for five years. To better support the family, his wife sells grocery items such as seasonings, soap, eggs, etc. to earn extra income. With the current business, his family can earn approximately KHR 66,700 per day to support their living costs. The main challenge of their business is low crop yields as a result of floods. 

Kai has been with VisionFund for one cycle and has successfully paid back the previous loan while the other member of his group has been with VisionFund for two cycles. The previous loan helped Kai with a better living standard. Now he is leading the group to apply for a loan with VisionFund. 

As the leader, Kai is going to use his portion to buy fertilizers for rice farming and will use some to buy grocery items to sell. He hopes this loan will enable his family to earn more income to improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for rice farming and grocery items to sell

loans.name: Uudus

texts.en:
Uudus, aged 43 , lives with her husband and her three sons in a small old house she owns in Ulaanbaatar city, Mongolia. Her younger son is a secondary school student. Her husband and two sons help with her business. She has been running her meat retail business in the local market for five years. Uudus already has many regular customers and suppliers. Her business is sustainable.

In the last few years, her old house has been very cold due to the heating loss through walls and windows. Therefore, Uudus has started to build her new house. The money she has saved is not enough for the new house. The loan that she is requesting will be used to build her new house with headers (beam-like supports) and vacuum (insulated) windows. Uudus is requesting a loan of 1,000,000 MNT to finish the house.

loans.use: To build her new house with headers and vacuum windows

loans.name: An

texts.en: An is requesting a new loan to buy materials to increase her production of candles. An's previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income to support her family. She hopes that another loan will assist her in increasing the size of her business, attracting new customers and increasing her sales. She also hopes that through the loan she can increase her income and improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To buy materials to increase her production of candles.

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 40-year-old Hawa in a rural area in Freetown. She is widowed with five children between the ages of 8 and 19 years. Her children are currently attending school. 

Hawa  runs a local goods store at the market square. She sells local goods like beans, cornflower, native rice and vegetable oil. She has been running this business for seven years. She began this business because when she lost her husband, she had no one to take care of her children's schooling.   She works at the business every day except holidays. Her other source of income comes from small-scale farming. At present she is faced with the problem of transportation. 

Hawa has requested a loan in order to buy more foodstuffs such as palm oil, bags of native rice, beans and dried peppers. The extra income from this loan will allow her to educate her children. She thanks you for your support!

video.title: Kiva Borrower Test from Sierra Leone

loans.use: To buy local foodstuffs such as palm oil, bags of native rice, beans and dried peppers.

loans.name: Abu

texts.en:
This is 28-year-old Abu.  He is married but has no child.  In 2009, Abu established his business selling jeans, bags, shoes, etc. He began his business because he lost his father who was paying his school fees, so he left school and decided to go into business so that he will be able to take care of himself and his family.  Working 7 days a week and 10 hours a day, he earns about Le 1,000,000 every month from this business. 

Abu would like a loan in the amount of Le 4,000,000. He requires this loan in order to buy more clothes so that he can realize more profits. In the future, Abu plans to get a better business and start selling wholesale.  He hopes to live a better life with his family.  He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more clothes so that he can realize more profits.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more stock to satisfy her customers' desire.

loans.name: Alex

texts.en:
This is 29-year-old Alex.  He is married and has 1 child, aged 4 years.  In 2007, Alex established his business selling mobile phones, DVDs and MP3. He began his business because he wants to support his family. Working 7 days a week and 9 hours a day, he earns about Le 1,000,000 every month from this business. 

Alex would like a loan in the amount of Le 5,000,000 in order to buy different types of mobile phones. In the future, Alex plans to become a leading mobile supplier in town. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy mobile phones to sell

loans.name: Nasser

texts.en:
Nasser is 28 years old and lives in the town of Luwero in the Luwero region of Uganda. He is married and has two children, one of whom is currently in school. For the past three years, Nasser has been working hard to manage his small business which sells phone accessories. 

To help expand his business, Nasser has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more phone accessories for resale and will help Nasser to generate greater profits, and pay school fees for his children. Nasser hopes that in the future he will be able to build more rental houses. 

Nasser is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Nasser who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more phone accessories for resale.

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac is 40 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala South region of Uganda. He is married and has three children who are all currently in school. For the past eight years, Isaac has been working hard to manage his stone quarry where he sells all types of stones. 

To help expand his business, Isaac has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more materials like a hammer that will be used for stone quarrying, and will help Isaac to generate greater profits and further expand his business by adding more other different hardware materials. Isaac hopes that in the future he will be able to own a hardware shop. 

Isaac is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Isaac who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more materials like a hammer that will be used for stone quarrying,

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet is 46 years old and lives in the town of Kasagati in the Kampala East region of Uganda. She is married and has 6 children with two of them currently in school. For the past 10 years, Juliet has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells household items like sugar. 

To help expand her business, Juliet has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase essential commodities like sugar and salt for resale, and will help Juliet to generate greater profits and increase her capital stock. Juliet hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business size. 

Juliet is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Juliet who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase essential commodities like sugar and salt for resale

loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en:
Sylvia is 26 years old and lives in the town of Nansana in the Kampala West region of Uganda. She is single and has 3 children with 2 currently in school. For the past 5 years, Sylvia has been working hard to manage her shop, which sells charcoal at retail and wholesale. 

To help expand her business, Sylvia has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more charcoal for resale. and will help Sylvia to generate greater profits and increase her capital stock. Sylvia hopes that in the future she will be able to start up a retail shop. 

Sylvia is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Sylvia who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Efuransi

texts.en:
Efuransi is 36 years old and lives in the town of Nansana in the Kampala West region of Uganda. She is widowed and has four children, three of whom are currently in school. For the past 12 years, Efuransi has been working hard to manage her clinic where she sells herbal medicine. 

To help expand her business, Efuransi has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more herbal medicine for resale, and will help Efuransi to generate greater profits and to increase the quality of services. Efuransi hopes that in the future she will be able to be self-reliant. 

Efuransi is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Efuransi who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more herbal medicine for resale

loans.name: Penina

texts.en:
Penina is 30 years old and lives in the town of Nansana in the Kampala West region of Uganda. She is married and has three children, one of whom is currently in school. For the past 7 years, Penina has been working hard to manage her small business that sells timber. 

To help expand her business, Penina has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more timber for resale, and will help Penina to generate greater profits and to increase her capital stock. Penina hopes that in the future, she will be able to grow her business to another branch. 

Penina is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Penina who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for micro-loans.

loans.use: to purchase more timber for resale,

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 32 years old and lives in the town of Nansana in the Kampala West region of Uganda. He is married and has three children, two of whom currently attend school. For the past five years, John has been working hard to manage his small business which sells timber. 

To help expand his business, John has requested a loan of 3,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more timber for resale, and will help John to generate greater profits and increase his capital stock. John hopes that in the future he will be able to start up another branch. 

John is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like John who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more timber for resale

loans.name: Suzan

texts.en:
Suzan is 29 years old and lives in the town of Nansana in the Kampala West region of Uganda. She is married and has 3 children who are all currently in school.  Suzan has been working hard to manage her small business, selling charcoal at retail and wholesale. 

To help expand her business, Suzan has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more charcoal for resale, and will help Suzan to generate greater profits and to expand her business by adding more sacks of charcoal. Suzan hopes that in the future she will be able to supply charcoal in the whole  town. 

Suzan is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Suzan who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for micro-loans.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal for resale

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is 35 years old and is married with five children, three of whom currently attend school. She lives in the town of Kasangati in the Kampala East region of Uganda. For the past three years, Beatrice has been working hard to manage her retail shop which sells essential commodities like sugar and soap. 

Beatrice is requesting a 2,000,000 UGX loan from BRAC Uganda to buy more essential commodities like sugar and soap for resale. Her loan will help her to generate greater profits and pay for necessities for her family. Beatrice hopes that in the future she will be able to build a residential house. 

Beatrice is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). This program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Beatrice who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more essential commodities like sugar and soap for resale.

loans.name: Musa

texts.en:
Musa is 30 years old and lives in the town of Nansana in the Kampala West region of Uganda. He is married and has two children who are both currently in school. For the past three years, Musa has been working hard to manage his business where he makes bricks. 

To help expand his business, Musa has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy fire wood for burning the bricks and also pay the workers, and will help Musa to generate greater profits and increase his income. Musa hopes that in the future he will be able to improve his capital inflow and start up another business. 

Musa is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Musa who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy fire wood for burning the bricks and also pay the workers

loans.name: Dorothy

texts.en:
Dorothy is 44 years old and lives in the town of Njeru in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is widowed and has two children who are currently in school. For the past three years, Dorothy has been working hard to manage her retail shop, where she sells cosmetics. 

Dorothy is requesting a 2,000,000 UGX loan from BRAC Uganda to buy more cosmetics and new brands. Her loan will help her generate greater profits and expand her inventory. Dorothy hopes that in the future she will be able to build rental houses. 

Dorothy is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Dorothy who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: buy new brands of cosmetics

loans.name: Americo

texts.pt:
CASADO e PAI de  4 filhos todos maiores de idade, vive na casa própria e não sustenta mais ninguém.
É agricultor, com o presente empréstimo pretende comprar material de construção (areia, cimento, portas, janelas, e PAGAMENTO DE CONTRACTO DE ENERGIA) para dar continuidade a obra da sua casa.
No futuro deseja concluir a sua casa e construir murro de vedação, para tal compromete-se a pagar o empréstimo devidamente para solicitar mais a Hluvuku. 
O desafio é o elevado custo e cuidar dos filhos.
texts.en:
Americo is single and the father of four children, all of them adults. He lives in a house he owns and doesn't support anyone else.
He's a farmer. With the current loan he intends to purchase construction supplies (sand, cement, doors, window frames), and also to pay his electricity bills, in order to continue building his house.
In the future he wishes to finish building his home and an enclosing wall. For that reason he pledges to repay the loan as scheduled, so he can request more from Hluvuku.
His challenge is high expenses and caring for his children.

loans.use: to purchase construction supplies (sand, cement, doors, window frames, etc.) in order to continue building his house.

loans.name: Sambalhundev

texts.en:
Sambalhundev is 49 years old and lives with his wife and his two children in an apartment that he owns in Darhan city, Mongolia. His two children are secondary school students. His wife is unemployed. 

Sambalhundev has been running a public transport business for the past 10 years. He wants to expand his business as his business income is not sufficient to provide for his family. Therefore, Sambalhundev is planning to run his transport business between Ulaanbaatar and Darhan. 

Also, his wife is planning to work in a document copying service at a rented workplace. The loan that he is requesting will be used to buy a copy machine and notepaper for his wife's new business. Sambalhundev is a diligent and honest man. He is requesting a loan of 2,500,000 MNT.

loans.use: To buy a copy machine and notepaper for his wife's new business

loans.name: Jumdah

texts.en:
Jumdah is 36 years old and is married with four children. She works hard to provide for her family. Jumdah has been running a general store in the Philippines for the past 14 years and also earns an income from raising chickens and cows and selling "copra" (dried coconut meat).

Jumdah has borrowed and repaid 11 loans from NWTF before this loan. She is now requesting a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stock to sell. Jumdah aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock to sell

loans.name: Liezl

texts.en:
Liezl is 42 years old and is married with four children. With two children in school, she works very hard to provide for them. Liezl has been running a general store in the Philippines for the past 15 years. She sells a variety of items such as canned goods, cream, bread, biscuits, etc. 

Liezl has requested a PHP 18,500 loan through NWTF to purchase items to sell. In the future, she would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: To purchase items to sell

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is a resident farmer in Nkubu, Central Kenya, where she produces milk, tea and vegetables. She has been in farming for thirty years with the help of one farmhand. She is married and has six adult children.

Agnes has requested a loan of 50,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy poultry birds. She says this will improve her farming income and make her independent and have better standards of living. She also plans to buy more land to expand her farming business.

Agnes says Juhudi Kilimo staff are doing a commendable job.

loans.use: buy poultry birds

loans.name: Lorena

texts.en:
Lorena is a hard-working entrepreneur who has a business buying and selling vegetables in the Philippines. She has been in this business for seven years. Lorena earns additional income from a general store.

Lorena has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF. She is borrowing PHP 16,000 through NWTF to purchase more vegetables to sell in her business. Lorena dreams of building and expanding her business to secure her family's future and to send her children to college.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Carmel

texts.en:
Carmel is a hard-working entrepreneur who has a welding shop business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 12 years. Carmel earns additional income from hog raising.

She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF. Carmel is borrowing PHP 29,500 through NWTF to buy tools and equipment for her welding shop business. She dreams of saving money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy tools and equipment for her welding shop.

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes is a hard-working entrepreneur who has a restaurant business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 20 years. Lourdes earns additional income from raising pigs.

She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF. Lourdes is borrowing PHP 24,000 through NWTF to purchase additional ingredients for her restaurant business. She dreams of repairing and renovating her family home in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients for her business

loans.name: Henerieta

texts.en:
Henerieta is 47 years old and from Nakuru. She is married and has four children who are aged between 23 and 13 years old.

Henerieta has a grocery business and a clothing business that she has been doing for the past twelve years and has applied for her first loan from KADET LTD to enable her to buy more clothes to sell.

She hopes to have a permanent place for operating her business,build a permanent house for her family and see to it that her businesses do well.

loans.use: to buy clothes to add to her stock.

loans.name: Marko Ekama

texts.en:
Marko operates a transport business commonly known as boda boda, and his wife sells charcoal. He ventured into this business three years ago and earns a monthly income of KES 10,300. 

Having repaid his previous loans, Marko is now requesting a third one for KES 55,000 to top up the amount he has already saved to purchase a motorbike. His profit will help him pay school fees for his children. 

His dream is to see his business grow and earn him enough money to meet his family's needs.

loans.use: to  purchase a new motorbike.

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac is 40 years old. He is married to Mary and together they have six children. He is a farmer and has been in the business for the past 12 years.  He gets a monthly income of KES 10,000 from his business.

This is his third loan from KADET LTD.He paid his previous loans well and in good time. He was introduced to KADET LTD by Credit officer. He will use the loan amount to purchase fertilizer and seedlings for planting.

He hopes to rent more farming land.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Fourty-year-old Rose is married to Luke and blessed with five children aged 20, 16, 13, 10 and two years respectively. She sells fish, a business she started 17 years ago and earns a monthly income of KES 15,000. 

She has requested her first loan of KES. 30,000 to purchase more fish for sale. The profit earned from the business will help her venture into another line of business. Her dream is to become a great businesswoman in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more fish for sale.

loans.name: Mathew

texts.en:
Mathew is 38 years old father of two children aged eight and five years old and he is married to Lucy. He is a farmer in Nyahururu town where he plants cash crops such as maize, beans and potatoes and he has been in the business for the past two years.

This being his first loan from KADET LTD, he plans to use the loan amount to buy chickens and start poultry farming. This will enable him to supply eggs and chickens to various hotels and thereby make more income with which he plans to pay school fees for his children.

In the future, Mathew hopes to invest more in his farming business, make more income and improve the living standards of his family.

loans.use: To buy chickens for poultry business.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
As a married parent of five children, Marilyn works hard to support her family. She has a food and fruit vending business in the Philippines. 

Marilyn has been sustaining her business activities through her past 16 loans from NWTF. She is borrowing PHP 16,000 through NWTF to buy additional stock to sell in her business. Marilyn hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of building and expanding her business to secure her family's future.

loans.use: To buy additional stock to sell in her stall

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
As a married parent of one child, Marivic works hard to support her family. She has a meat retail business in the Philippines and earns additional income from selling frozen foods.  Marivic is borrowing PHP 18,000 through NWTF to purchase additional meat to sell in her business.

Marivic has been sustaining her business activities through her past nine loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving money to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional meat to sell

loans.name: Mary Suzzete

texts.en:
Mary Suzzete is 37 years old and is married with three children. She works hard to provide for her family. Mary Suzzete has been running a general store in the Philippines for the past 15 years and earns additional income from raising livestock.

Mary Suzzete has borrowed and repaid four loans from NWTF before this loan. She is now requesting a PHP 10,500 loan through NWTF to buy additional items for her general store. Mary Suzzete aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: To buy additional items for her general store

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
As a married parent of two children, Merlita works hard to support her family. She has a motorcycle transport business in the Philippines, and earns additional income from buying and selling fish and mineral water. Merlita is borrowing PHP 25,000 through NWTF to purchase spare parts for maintenance for her motorcycle transport business.

Merlita has been sustaining her business activities through her past seven loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for motorcycle maintenance

loans.name: Tsuma

texts.en:
Tsuma is 35 year old bookshop proprietor in Mariakani. He is a married  with five school going children. His business has been in operation for the past nine years and it is doing great.
 
This is his third business loan from KADET LTD to finance his business. He plans to purchase textbooks, exercise books, and geometrical sets for sale. He will use the anticipated profits to plough back into the business. 

He hopes to have a bigger, more profitable business.

loans.use: to purchase textbooks, exercise books, and geometrical sets.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is 26 years old and is married to Eva.  They have one child, who is one year old.

Samuel has a transportation business in which he transports wholesale goods to various retail shops. He has applied for his first loan from KADET LTD to buy more goods in bulk, like soaps, soft drinks, and cooking oil for supply to the retail shops.

He hopes to buy a piece of land and build a house for his family in the near future.

loans.use: to buy more goods in bulk, like soaps, soft drinks, and cooking oil, for supply to retail shops.

loans.name: Festus

texts.en:
Festus is  31 year old tailor in Mikindani, Mombasa. He is a married father of two children. He has been sewing clothes for his customers for the past eight years with great success.  

This is Festus’ fourth loan from KADET LTD to finance his business. He plans to purchase a new sewing machine, sewing thread, and cloth materials. He will use the anticipated profits to buy a piece of land to build business premises. 

He hopes to have a prosperous life.

loans.use: to purchase a new sewing machine, sewing thread, and cloth materials for his tailoring business.

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en:
Mohamed is a businessman living in Likoni town, Kenya. He carries out farming as a source of income. Mohamed began the business twenty years ago and besides this, he also sells fruit juice.

Mohamed learned of Milango from him friends. He was introduced to Milango this year and is applying for a loan of 41,850 Kenyan shillings to purchase more coconuts to sell. The coconuts are used in many meals in the coastal area. His aspiration is to supply to other major towns in the country.
