loans.use: to buy more shirts, trousers and vegetables to resell.

loans.name: Le

texts.en:
Le is a 42-year-old married woman who operates a rice farming business to help her husband earn income for the family. She has been in this business since she was a teenager living with her parents. So, she has many years of experience in this field. Le just owns a few plots of farmland and she plans to expand her land size to yield a good output. 

Due to the lack of capital, she is asking for a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase more land for farming purpose. With the help of the loan, Le will be able to improve her current business and thereby increase her household income. She is responsible for a school-aged child who is in need of her daily allowances.

loans.use: to purchase more land for farming purpose.

loans.name: Sokhom's Group

texts.en:
Sokhom is 42 years old and divorced. She has four children, two of whom are working as paid workers in Thailand. She lives in a rural village of the Thmor Koul district of Battambang province, Cambodia. For the past 15 years, Sokhom has been farming a two-hectare plot of farmland to provide for her family. She earns about 140,000 KHR per day.

Sokhom is requesting her first group loan with VisionFund. She and another female member will each receive 1,000,000 KHR. Sokhom is the group leader and will use her portion of the loan to buy fertilizer for her dry-season rice. In the future, she hopes to earn more income from her cash crop to provide for a better lifestyle.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her farm

loans.name: Pascal

texts.en:
Pascal is married with 3 children. His wife is also a maize farmer. He has been a maize farmer for 6 years. He would like to get this loan to buy more seeds for seed multiplication and to support labor to get the best harvest. With the profits, he wants to buy cows for providing milk for the family. 
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more seeds for seed multiplication and to support labor costs.

loans.name: Eglecerio

texts.en:
Eglecerio is married with 5 children. He is 43 years old and resides at Montol, Ozamis City, Philippines.

Eglecerio is operating a crop raising venture, planting & harvesting corn for sale in the local community to earn a living. He has been in this business for 20 years. Each month, he earns 8,000 PHP doing this type of business.

He requested a loan of 8,300 PHP to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Eglecerio joined GDMPC in 2011. In the future, Eglecerio wants to save as a reserve for future emergencies and to purchase another piece of farmland.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Marichelle

texts.en:
Marichelle is 29 years old and is single with a child. She is from Mialen, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. For over the past three years, Marichelle has owned and operated a motorcycle transport service. She earns 10,000 PHP a month. Marichelle joined GDMPC in 2009.

Marichelle is requesting a 16,000 PHP loan to purchase spare parts and accessories. She plans to use the additional revenue generated with her loan to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase vehicle spare parts and accessories

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina is 62 years old and from the community of Talibon, Bohol. She is married and has seven children. Her eldest is 29 years old and her youngest is 18. She is engaged in food vending, which is her main source of livelihood. Josefina usually cooks biko (sweetened glutinous rice, mixed with brown sugar, and usually mashed), budbud (slightly sweet sticky rice wrapped in banana leaves and coconut milk), and suman (a rice cake made from glutinous rice cooked in coconut milk and often steamed in banana leaves). 

Josefina wants to increase her production and would like to ask for a loan to buy ingredients like coconut, sugar, and sticky rice. Any income will be used for her family's daily consumption and school fees for her children and grandchildren.

loans.use: to buy ingredients like coconut, sugar, and sticky rice

loans.name: Benediction Group

texts.fr: La cliente Pendeza est secrétaire  du groupe de crédit  Bénédiction, Femme dynamique, cliente au 15e cycle de crédit. Elle est mère de 7 enfants. Son mari est actuellement chômeur (sans emploi). Elle est vendeuse de divers. Elle a commencé son business avec son fond propre reçu de son mari, Elle expose ses marchandises au  marché public du secteur Alanine. Environs 8 ans, elle exerce cette activité génératrice de revenu.  Avec le crédit de l’IMF Hekima, la cliente  souhaite accroitre son chiffre d’affaire en achetant les articles divers (Omo, sucre, pétrole, lotion de beauté, Fanta, souliers, etc.). Le  défi  actuel  dans son activité, c’est la multiplicité de taxes dit-elle. Dans l’avenir, elle ambitionne accroitre son entreprise, construire confortablement, scolariser ses enfants et  voir son mari trouver du travail. Elle remercie l’IMF Hekima, pour les crédits réguliers qu’elle reçoit sans aucune garantie matérielle, car grâce à ces crédits, elle parvient à subvenir aux multiples besoins de sa famille.
texts.en: The borrower Pendeza is the secretary of the loan group Bénédiction.  A dynamic woman, she is on her 15th loan cycle.  She is the mother of seven children.  Her husband is currently unemployed.  She sells various items.  She started her business with money that her husband gave her.  She makes her sales at the public market in the Alanine sector.  She has been earning money with this type of work for about eight years.   With money from the IMF Hekima loan, this borrower hopes to increase her turnover by stocking up on various items (Omo detergent, sugar, gasoline, cosmetic lotions, Fanta, shoes, etc.).  She says that presently, the challenge in this type of work is the amount of taxes.  In the future, she hopes to grow her business, improve the comfort of her home, educate her children, and see that her husband finds work.  She would like to thank IMF Hekima for the regular loans that she receives without any collateral.  It is because of these loans that she is able to meet the many needs of her family.

loans.use: to buy various items such as Omo detergent, sugar, gasoline, cosmetic lotions, Fanta, shoes, etc.

loans.name: Gs Soni I Group

texts.es:
Doña Hegdomilia es una persona muy emprendedora dedicada a su negocio, vive con su esposo y sus 4 hijos. En Choluteca en el sur de Honduras. Y tiene más de 10 años de tener este tipo de negocio de pulperia.
El préstamo lo invertirá en la compra de maíz, refrescos, azúcar, café, pan, harina, arroz, frijoles y verduras, de esta manera incrementar más sus ventas. Con el préstamo espera mejorar sus ventas y asi atender mejor a sus clientes. Con estos fondos espera que su negocio sea más sólido y rentable.
Doña Hemigdonia sus sueños es poder  y darles a sus hijos una  mejor educación y ayudar a su familia.
Octavio se dedica a su negocio propio pulpería desde hace mas de 7 años en el mercado de esa zona.
Gustavo se dedica su negocio propio compra y venta de ganado. Desde hace mas de 3 años en varios caseríos de la zona.
Choluteca, Honduras - Junio del 2012
texts.en:
Hegdomilia is an enterprising woman dedicated to her work. She lives with her husband and 4 children in Choluteca in southern Honduras and has been running a grocery store for more than 10 years. She will use this loan to buy corn, soft drinks, sugar, coffee, bread, flour, rice, beans, and vegetables to increase her sales and provide better service to her customers. She hopes her business will be more stable and profitable with this funding.

Hemigdonia dreams of giving her children a better education and helping her family.
Octavio has had his own local grocery store for more than 7 years.
Gustavo has been buying and selling livestock in local villages for over 3 years.
Choluteca, Honduras - June 2012

loans.use: to buy corn, soft drinks, sugar, coffee, bread, flour, rice, beans, and vegetables for her business.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel currently earns income by operating a goat meat business and a retail kiosk. These are the only sources of income that he has to support his family. He does this work to cover his family’s expenses for food, education, and basic services.

Emmanuel needs a loan to purchase more livestock for resale. His dream is to expand his businesses and purchase a grinding machine in future. This way he will improve his family's quality of life.

This is the third time he has requested a loan from Yehu and the second time he has requested a loan from Kiva. Thanks to Kiva and Yehu for their support.

loans.use: to purchase more livestock for resale.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Lucy is from Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 37 years old. Lucy is married and has three children. Lucy used her last loan to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. Her business has grown and become successful. Now, she is taking a new loan to purchase additional products like canned goods, noodles, sugar, and coffee. Lucy he hopes to be able to grow her business more.

loans.use: to purchase additional products like canned goods, noodles, sugar, and coffee.

loans.name: Vicheka's Group

texts.en:
Vicheka is 30 and is married with one daughter who is still under her responsibility. She lives in a village of the Dambae district of Cambodia where she farms sweet potatoes and rice on three hectares of land. Vicheka has been a farmer for two years and earns around 23,600 KHR per day. She has been with VisionFund for one loan cycle and has successfully paid back her entire loan which enabled her to have decent food. Vicheka is self-confident.

Vicheka is the leader of a three-member group requesting a new loan. She will use her portion of the loan to plow her farmland. In the future, Vicheka hopes to keep her children in school and to have a big, decent house for her family.

loans.use: to plow her farmland

loans.name: Chantal

texts.en:
Chantal is married and has seven children. Five of them attend school. She has been a maize farmer for 13 years. Her husband is also a maize farmer. She would like to get this loan to buy and harvest more seeds and to support labor to get the best harvest. With the profits, she wants to reinvest in her business.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy and harvest seeds and to support labor costs.

loans.name: Beezandan

texts.en:
Mr. Beezandan, 57, works as a watchman in a primary school. Before this, he used to work as a driver. All of his children moved out from their parent’s house. Now he lives with his wife and nephew in Kherlen, an eastern boundary town in Mongolia. One of his daughters lives in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Recently, his daughter purchased a plot of land and an old house in the 'ger' district (ger is a Mongolian nomadic tent).  The house needed a complete renovation or repair. Especially, she is planning to replace its windows to double-glazed ones first due to too much heat loss and emissions through the old ones.  But she lacks money to cover the cost of new windows. 

Her father Beezandan decided to help his daughter to repair her home. She believes her house will become warmer and the cost of coal will be cut notably. Although Mongolia has the lowest population density in the world, it is one of the most polluted countries in the world.  This is due to the long and cold winters where temperatures frequently go below -40C (-40F) even in the cities.  Also, in winter, many parts of the country are extremely cold and are known to have snow storms.  Both homes and nomadic tents burn a lot of fuel and emit huge amounts of pollution every night from families just trying to stay warm.  As well, the extremely toxic smoke from the cars is a main reason of Mongolia's air pollution. 

In response to this, Credit Mongol offers Green Loans to their clients to make home improvements that reduce heat loss, improve heating systems and to buy the cars running on natural gas. The loan Beezandan is taking will be used to cover the cost of the new double-glazed windows for his daughter’s house.

loans.use: To cover the cost of new double-glazed windows for his daughter’s house

loans.name: Batzaya

texts.en:
Batzaya is 24 and lives with her husband, parents, and a son in an apartment she owns in Darhan province, Mongolia. Her husband works for a mining company in South Gobi province and her father works as a repairer. Batzaya used to be a shop assistant at her sister’s shoe store and she worked on salary. In January 2012, she started her own business and rented a space to retail shoes. Her mother helps with her business. Batzaya started her business with 1,000,000 MNT in working capital and now has increased her working capital to 5,000,000 MNT. Batzaya already has many regular costumers and wants to expand her business as in the summer product demand is high and she would like to purchase more merchandise to sell.

Batzaya is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to buy summer shoes for 1,500,000 MNT, children clothing for 2,000,000 MNT, and fund transportation costs with 300,000 MNT. She is a hardworking and good natured woman.

loans.use: to buy summer shoes, children clothes, and pay transportation costs

loans.name: Judith

texts.en: Judith is married with 3 children. Judith is 36-years-old and resides in Cabungaan Clarin, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. Judith used her last loan to have additional capital for a lumber business. Her business is successful. She is taking a new loan for her transport business to purchase spare vehicle parts and accessories. In the future she hopes to be able to grow her business.

loans.use: to purchase spare vehicle parts and accessories

loans.name: Hamid

texts.ru: Hamid 23 qoda. On jivet v Baku regione vmeste so svoyey semyoy. Hamid ne jenat i ne imeyet detey. Uje 3 qoda kak Hamid zanimayetsya prodajey loshadey. On pokupayet loshadey kogda oni bivayet malenkimi, potom koqda oni vzrosleyut on prodayot ix. Tem samim on zarobativayet dengi dlya soderjaniya sebya i svoyey semyi. Hamid seychas nujdayetsya v 1500 AZN chtobi kupit korm dlya loshadey dlya zimi. Hamid xochet razvit svoy bizness i uvelichit kolichestvo loshadey v budushem.
texts.en: Hamid is 23 years old. He lives in the Baku Region together with his relatives. Hamid is single, without children. For three years, he has been selling horses. He buys young horses, raises them and then resells. This is how he earns a living for himself and his relatives. At present, Hamid needs 1500 AZN in order to buy winter feed for his horses. Hamid would like to expand his business and increase the number of horses in the future.

loans.use: to buy horse feed.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks, and beverages.

loans.name: Junie

texts.en: Junie  is  52  years old and lives in the Philippines. He is married with 7 children. Junie  has a food/retail shop or sari-sari store that buys & sells canned goods, snacks, personal care products, home use products & beverages. Aside from that he also sells viand like adobo, fried chicken and kare-kare. He had this business for 6 years.He requested a loan for 8,000  to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks & beverages. Junie has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Junie hopes to improve his business for the education of his children.

loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Sophie

texts.en:
Sophie is married and has four children. All her children are enrolled in schools. She has been a maize farmer for 3 years. Her husband is also a maize farmer. Sophie would like to get this loan to buy more seeds, to harvest seeds, and to support labor costs to get the best harvest. With the profits, she wants to the pay school fees for her children.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy and harvest more seeds and to support labor costs.

loans.name: Batlut

texts.en:
Batlut, 52, lives with her husband and four children in a ger (a Mongolian yurt) in Tosontsengel, Mongolia. Her husband is a disabled man who receives social welfare from state. Batlut started her business cutting organic hay with a rental tractor in 2011. Her husband and children help with her business. She sells her organic hay to local herders. Her business is sustainable and she has already gotten many regular customers. But, her business income is not sufficient to provide for her family.  

Batlut wants to expand her business. Therefore, she needs to buy her own tractor. She is hardworking and a good natured woman. She said, "I have worked for my children's future. I want to increase my business income in order to provide enough money for my family." She is requesting 2,200,000 MNT to buy her own tractor to use in her business.

loans.use: To buy her own tractor.

loans.name: Weldita

texts.en:
This is Weldita, 51, resident of Cavite, Philippines. She has one child. She manages their household while operating a business.

Weldita runs a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Gemma buys products at wholesale prices and sells them by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She brings in a minimum of Php600 in sales every day.

She is requesting a Php 12,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory, and to service her sewing machine. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Weldita hopes to expand her business through all her hard work. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week. She can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God as they study together.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional supplies and products.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy items like beans, kejje and onions

loans.name: Benediction De Dieu Group

texts.fr:
Mr  GUIBRINA est le représentant du groupe BENEDICTION DE DIEU. Il est marié et père d’un enfant. L’enfant a 02ans et ne va pas à l’école. Il a 03 personnes en charge.

Mr vend des verres DURALEXE  depuis 02ans. Il s’approvisionne au Ghana et au Nigeria. Ses clients sont les gérants de maquis, bar et kiosque.

Il veut s’acheter  08 cartons de verres.

Il utilise ses bénéfices pour améliorer  son activité et agrandir son hangar. Mr ambitionne préparer la scolarisation de son enfant, et construire dans sa futur parcelle qui sera loti bientôt.
texts.en:
Mr. Guibrina is the leader of the BENEDICTION DE DIEU group.  He is married and the father of one child.  The child is two years old and does not go to school.  He has three people in his care.

Mr. Guibrina has been selling Duralexe glasses for two years.  He gets his supplies in Ghana and in Nigeria.  His customers are managers of bars and kiosks. 

He wants to buy 8 cases of glasses.

He will use his profits to improve his business and to enlarge his storage space.  Mr. Guibrina’s ambition is to prepare for his child’s education and to build on his future plot of land which will be divided out soon.

loans.use: to buy 8 cases of glasses.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy items like meat and beans.

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Merlinda provides transportation services within her town using her motorized tricycle. She is married and has three children ages three, six and eight. She and her family live in San Jose, Talibon, Bohol.

Merlinda is in need of a loan so that she can buy spare parts and pay the vulcanizing fee for her vehicle. The tricycle is her main source of livelihood, so once it is fixed, she can earn the daily income needed to meet her family's needs. Any additional income will pay for her children's schooling and the pursuit of possible new business opportunities.

loans.use: to buy spare parts and pay for vulcanizing.

loans.name: Ganijon

texts.en: Ganijon is cute, brainy and kind-hearted. He is a young and reasonable person. Ganijon has a lot of friends. His friends love him very much and always help him in his deals. For more than 12 years he has been busy with animal husbandry. His business has developed year after year as he works very hard. Ganijon buys cattle, cares for them and then sells them to the local people. He wants to develop his business further to earn more income. He is asking for a loan to buy young cattle to expand his business. If you want to help anybody, please, help Ganijon. He awaits your help and support.

loans.use: To buy cattle for his developing business.

loans.name: Rim

texts.en:
Residing in a rural area located in the Ponhea Krek district of Kompong Cham province, Cambodia, Rim is 37 years old and married. She has four dependent children, three daughters and one son, all of whom are still in school. 

Rim is a farmer who has been growing rice and planting potatoes for 10 years. Rim received her first loan from VisionFund in 2011, and completely repaid the entire loan. The past loan has helped her family make a better living. Now she can earn about 25,000 KHR per day. Rim is applying for a new loan of 1,500,000 KHR to buy fertilizers for her farmland. She hopes to increase the amount of land suitable for growing more potatoes so that she can earn more profits.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for her farmland

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ponhea Krek district

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more coconuts and green banana to resell

loans.name: Eugenie

texts.en:
Eugenie is married and has two children. Both of them are still young. She has been a maize farmer for six years. Her husband is also a maize farmer.  She would like to get this loan to buy more seeds, to harvest seeds, and to pay for labor to get the best harvest. With the profits, she wants to save more.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy and harvest more seeds and to support labor costs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Seraphine

texts.en:
Seraphine is married with two children, both of whom are still young. Her husband is also a maize farmer. She has been a maize farmer for 10 years. She would like a loan to buy more seeds and pay for labor to get the best harvest. With the profits, she wants to increase her savings.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more seeds and pay for labor costs.

loans.name: Melody

texts.en:
Melody, 30, is a resident of Cavite City, Philippines. She has two children with her husband, Leopoldo, a security guard.  Together with her husband and children, she manages the household while running her business.

Melody runs a variety store next to her house. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which sells groceries, toiletries and beverages to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, five pesos' worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Melody makes a profit by purchasing supplies at wholesale prices and selling items individually at retail prices. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 600 Philippine pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue to run her business, Melody is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan. She will be using the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory and to maintain her sewing machine. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Melody hopes her business will grow into a mini grocery store and dreams to be able to give her children a good and high quality education due to her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional stock to sell in her store.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is married and has six children, between the ages of 5 and 15. He has been a maize farmer for 20 years. His wife is also a maize farmer. He would like to get this loan to buy more seeds, to harvest more seeds, and to pay for labor to get the best harvest. With the profits, he would like to reinvest in the same agriculture business.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy and harvest more seeds and to support labor costs.

loans.name: Savan's Group

texts.en: Savan, age 28, is a married mother of one dependent son living in the Ek Phnom district of Battambang province, Cambodia. On her two hectares of farmland, she has been growing paddy rice and planting watermelons and cucumbers. She has been in these businesses for ten years. Her main challenge is the crop yields which have been destroyed by flooding in the past year. This is the second cycle for Savan with KIVA’s partner, VisionFund. She has successfully paid back her first loan, which enabled her to build a proper house for her family. With the other two members of the group which she is leading, Savan is applying for a loan of 1,200,000 KHR. One member is requesting a loan for 1,400,000 KHR and the other is seeking a loan for 800,000 KHR. With this loan, Savan is going to buy fertilizers and rice seeds for her farmland. In the future, she hopes to make a better living.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and rice seeds for her farmland.

loans.name: Eliezer

texts.en:
Eliezer is married with five children aged between 12 and 32. He has been a maize farmer for 20 years. His wife is also a maize farmer. He would like to use this loan to buy more seeds and pay for the labor to get the best harvest. With the profits, he wants to buy a cow.
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more seeds and pay for labor costs.

loans.name: Marcelinda

texts.en:
Marcelinda is a farmer in the town of Talibon, Bohol. She is 57 years old, married and has seven adult children.
She has been farming corn and rice for 30 years now. She is also engaged in fishing and crab-catching businesses. Marcelinda's husband is helping her in their business. Marcelinda  would like to improve her income by improving her fishing activity. She is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer and crab traps which will enable her to be more productive and to catch more crabs. Her profit will allow her to buy nutritious food for her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and crab traps

loans.name: Claudio

texts.en:
Claudio is a 43 year-old married man residing in Talibon, Bohol, Philippines. Claudio has run a motorcycle business for 20 years. He is also in a farming business where he grows rice. 

Claudio is asking for a loan worth 5000PHP to buy spare parts for motorcycle repair and to buy fertilizer for the plants in his farm. 
In the future, Claudio aims to improve his motorcycle business and farming to generate more income so that he will able to meet the needs of his family and for the education of his four children, ages 19, 17, 14 and eleven. He believes that education is really important for a better future.

loans.use: to buy spare motorcycle parts and plant fertilizer

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Kumba

texts.en:
To meet his household's diverse needs, Kumba sells clothes in a boutique. He also farms to supplement his first business. He has been in this business for over fifteen years in this region. He buys his supplies from a region in Kenya. Thanks to the revenue that this business generates, he helps cover his household expenses.

To meet the needs of his burgeoning customer base, Kumba is requesting a second loan from both Kiva and Yehu. Kumba dreams of opening a new boutique and hiring an employee in the future. This loan will enable him to purchase more bundles of clothes to stock his boutique.

loans.use: to purchase more bundles of clothes.

loans.name: El Rapha Group

texts.fr:
Mr  HAMADO est le représentant du groupe EL RAPHA. Il est célibataire sans enfant. Personne  ne va à l’école. Il n’a personne en charge.

Mr vend des habits prêt à porter (maillots, survêtements  complet)  depuis 06ans. Il s’approvisionne au marché de secteur 10. Ses clients sont les hommes.

Il veut s’acheter  10 douzaines de maillots et survêtements.

Il utilise ses bénéfices pour renforcer  son activité. Mr ambitionne effectuer des voyages à l’étranger pour s’approvisionner.
texts.en:
Mr. Hamado is the leader of the  EL RAPHA group.  He is single and has no children, so there is no one who attends school.   He has no one else in his care. 

Mr. Hamado has been selling ready to wear clothing (jerseys, warm-up suits) for six years.  He gets his supplies at the market in sector 10.   His customers are men. 

He wants to buy 10 dozen jerseys and warm-up suits. 

He will use his profits to build up his business.  Mr.  Hamado would like to be able to travel abroad to get buy his merchandise.

loans.use: to buy 10 dozen jerseys and warm-up suits.

loans.name: Pol

texts.en:
Pol is 60 years old and a humble villager living in Baray district of Kompong Tom province. He is married and has eight children - two married children and six single children. He is a very hard-working man who is eager to raise his family out of poverty and get ahead in his businesses. He is involved in a farming business, primarily growing rice for daily sustenance and for sale. At the same time, he raises a few piglets for fattening in his backyard. Some of his teenaged children help him in managing the two businesses.

To improve his business and earn a better living, Pol is requesting a loan of KHR 2,000,000 to purchase a used motorbike for his business and household transportation needs. He is very grateful for the loan granted because he will be able to go a long way.

loans.use: to purchase a used motorbike for his business and household transportation needs.

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean is married and has six children. He has been a maize farmer for 10 years. His wife is also a maize farmer. He would like to get this loan to buy more seeds, to harvest more seeds, and to pay for labor to get the best harvest. With the profits, he wants to buy more plots for growing maize.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy and harvest more seeds and to support labor costs.

loans.name: Rommel

texts.en:
Rommel is a 37-year-old married man with four children. The oldest child is about 16 years old and the youngest is seven. Rommel's wife works as a house helper in the neighborhood.

Rommel is a farmer and at the same time a carpenter working in San Jose, Talibon, Bohol, Philippines. Rommel has been growing rice for 20 years now. Rommel joined CEVI hoping that he could get financial support for his business. He is asking for a loan worth 4,000 PHP, which he will use to finance his farm and for the maintenance of equipment used in the rice field such as the tractor and thresher. In addition, to he wants to buy additional materials for carpentry such as nails and other things. In the future, Rommel hopes to improve his business in order to experience the fullness of life together with his family.

loans.use: to pay for the maintenance of equipment used in the rice field such as the tractor and thresher

loans.name: Jean De Dieu

texts.en:
Jean De Dieu is married and has four children. He has been a maize farmer for nine years. His wife is also a maize farmer. He would like to get this loan to buy more seeds, to harvest more seeds, and to pay for labor to get the best harvest. With the profits, he wants to reinvest in the same business of growing maize.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy and harvest more seeds and to support labor costs.

loans.name: Tsevelmaa

texts.en:
Tsevelmaa, 40, lives with her husband and her two children in an apartment she owns in Khovd province, Mongolia. Her husband helps with her business. Her elder son is a kindergarten student. She recently adopted a child. 

Tsevelmaa started her garment retail business in 2000.  Her business is sustainable and she has many regular customers and suppliers. Starting this year, she has begun to sell wool and cashmere products. She wants to expand her business. She was able to buy an apartment due to her business profits. In the future, she plans to buy a hybrid car.  Tsevelmaa is a hardworking woman. She is requesting 5,000,000 MNT to purchase a hybrid car for her family.

loans.use: To purchase a hybrid car for her family.

loans.name: Marie Alice

texts.en:
Marie Alice is married with no children. She has been a maize farmer for eight years. Her husband is also a maize farmer. She would like to get this loan to buy more seeds, to harvest more seeds, and to pay for labor to get the best harvest. With the profits, she wants to save more for the better future of her career.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy and harvest more seeds and to support labor costs.

loans.name: Soeurn's Group

texts.en:
Living in the rural Dambae District of Kompong Cham Province, Cambodia, Soeurn is 53 years old. She is married and has three children, including one son who still needs her support as he earns minimal income as a farmer. Soeurn has been planting potatoes on three-hectare of farmland for 25 years. The main challenge for her is the dropping price of potatoes in the market and her children's sickness.

This is the second loan cycle for Soeurn and the first loan for her other two members. She has paid back her first loan which has helped her to make a better living and earn about 27,000 KHR per day. She and one of her group members are each requesting a loan of 1,000,000 KHR each while another one is applying for 500,000 KHR.

As the group leader, Soeurn is going to use her loan to buy fertilizers for her farmland. She hopes that price of potatoes will increase and she can receive more crop yield so that she can earn more profit.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticides for her farmland

loans.name: Dorine

texts.en:
Dorine is a married mother and has a single eleven year-old son who is in school. Her husband, James, is an education officer in the region. Approximately six years ago, she started to work selling farm produce. Afterwards, thanks to some savings, she started a bookshop which she has been working in since then. In addition to her husband's income, her bookshop has guaranteed the income necessary to sustain her household.
 
Thanks to her growing sales, Dorine will expand her business. To do this, she is looking for a loan to purchase basic stationery such as textbooks and other office materials to stock her bookshop. In this way, she will keep growing and thus, continue expanding her sales, allowing her a better household income which will offer her son a better quality of life. Her dream is to have a great business that will last for many years and continue meeting her needs, as well as allow her to offer her son a good quality education and an economically stable future.

loans.use: to purchase basic stationery such as text books and other office materials

loans.name: Tserendolgor

texts.en: Tserendolgor, 49, lives with her daughter in a small house in Bulgan province, Mongolia.  Her daughter is a specialist for the local government. She runs a garment retail business at a rental counter. She already has many regular customers and suppliers. She wants to expand her business.  During the national holiday, the demand for summer-style garments increases. Thus, she needs to buy summer clothes to sell at her retail counter in order to increase her business income as well as profit. She is a diligent, hardworking, and humble woman. She is requesting 2,000,000 MNT to purchase more summer clothes to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more summer clothes to sell

loans.name: Silas

texts.en:
Silas is married with seven children between one-and-a-half and eighteen years old. He has been a maize farmer for 10 years. His wife is also a maize farmer. He would like to get this loan to buy more seeds and support labor costs to get the best harvest. With the profits, he wants to buy more plots for growing maize.
The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under-served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more seeds and support labor costs.

loans.name: Afya Group

texts.fr: La cliente Kahindo est membre du le groupement  d’affaire Afya, elle est mariée et mère de 8 jeunes enfants. Son mari  est un maçon constructeur. La cliente est vendeuse de braises. Elle est sociétaire d’un entrepôt de stockage de braises. Elle commença son entreprise avec son fonds propre, alors qu’elle venait de vendre une partie de son champ. Plus tard, elle sollicita le soutien de l’IMF Hekima. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner avec  4 sacs de braises. Le grand défi qu’elle connait dans son activité est la multiplicité de taxe et tracasserie policière et administrative. Ainsi, elle remercie Hekima pour son appui  et autonomisation des petits entrepreneurs femmes.Il sied de signaler qu’une cliente porte son bébé.
texts.en:
Kahindo, a member of the business group Afya, is a married mother of eight young children. Her husband is a mason carpenter. 

Kahindo sells charcoal, and she is a partner in a charcoal storage facility. She started her business with her own funds after selling part of her land. Later, she turned to the Hekima MFI for financial support. 

She will use this new loan to buy four bags of charcoal. Her main challenges are the multiple taxes, difficulties brought on by police, and administrative red tape. 

Kahindo wishes to thank the Hekima MFI for helping female owners of small businesses to become self-sufficient. 

Note: One of the group members is holding her baby in the photo.

loans.use: to buy four bags of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy tools and gasoline

loans.name: Pilar

texts.en: Pilar is married with 3 children. Pilar is 38-years-old and lives in the Philippines. Pilar operates a service-based business, providing transportation services to local community members to earn a living. She's been doing this for 5 years and earns 6,000PHP a month from this work. She has requested a loan of 13,500PHP to repair a transport vehicle used in her business. In 2009, Pilar joined GDMPC. In the future, Pilar hopes to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to repair a transport vehicle used in her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy organic vegetable seeds.

loans.name: L'aenir Group

texts.fr:
Mme AISSATOU est responsable du groupe L’AENIR. Elle est mariée et mère de 03 enfants. Le plus âgé a 12ans et le moins âgé a 05ans. Tous vont à l’école. Elle a 01 personne en charge.

Mme vend des produits de beautés et fait aussi la coiffure depuis 10ans. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché et au marché du secteur 10. Ses clients sont son entourage.

Elle veut s’acheter 40 dizaines de tissage et 02 dizaines de mèche.

Mme veut investir ses bénéfices dans son commerce. Elle ambitionne s’occuper de sa famille, payer une parcelle et assurer la scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Mrs. Aissatou is the head of the L’Aenir group. She is married and the mother of three children. The oldest is 12 years old, and the youngest five years old. All children are in school. She has one other dependent.

Mrs. Aissatou has been selling beauty products and working as a hairdresser for 10 years. She stocks up at the big market and  at the Sector 10 market. Her customers are from her own community. She would like to buy 40 dozens hair weaves and two dozens of hair extensions.

loans.use: to buy 40 dozens hair weaves and two dozens of hair extensions.

loans.name: Azamjon

texts.en: Azamjon is a man who has realized all his plans. He is reasoned and hardworking. He has own business deal. For more than 10 years he has been busy producing boxes and selling them to local people. His experiences have helped him to be successful in business. He has a friendly family. He tries to do the best for his children. His brother helps him in business. He wants to develop his business further but for this he needs a car. He is asking for a loan to buy a car for developing his business. He awaits your help and support.

loans.use: to buy a car for developing his business.

loans.name: Shijirbold

texts.en: Shijirbold,32, lives with his wife and his son in ger (Mongolian yurt) in Ulaanbaatar city, Mongolia. His son is a secondary school student. His wife helps with his business. He moved in Ulaanbaatar in 2006 from countryside. He was a herder in countryside. He started his dairy production business in 2007.  His business is sustainable and has many regular customers. He is a humble and responsible man. He said "I usually try to provide to costumers quality and health dairy products. Healthy cows produce high quality milk. I need to buy good and quality fodder for my cows."  He is requesting 2,500,000 MNT to buy organic fodder.

loans.use: To buy organic fodder for his dairy cows

loans.name: Sa Em

texts.en: Sa Em is 56 years old living in the Ponhea Krek district of Cambodia. She is a mother of five children. Two of her daughters still need her support. She and her husband grow rice on a small plot of farmland and plant potatoes on two hectares of leased land; she has been with these businesses for 27 years. To better feed her family, she also works for others for pay while her husband plays a traditional musical instrument during weddings for a fee. Together, they are able to earn around 32,000 KHR per day. She has been with VisionFund for one cycle and completely paid back the past loan, which improved her living condition. Now she is seeking a new loan of 3,000,000 KHR to buy fertilizers for her farmland. In the future, she hopes that the price of potatoes will increased so that she can earn more income for her family’s sake.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers for her farmland

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ponhea Krek district

loans.name: Francoise

texts.en:
Francoise is married and has two children who are 2 and 14 years old. Her older child goes to school and her husband works as a maize farmer. She has worked with him for the last six years and would like to get a loan to buy more seeds and hire workers to help get the best possible harvest. She will use a portion of her increased profits to pay her child's school fees. 

Agriculture accounts for 37 percent of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65 percent of Rwanda's export revenue and employs about 90 percent of Rwanda's population (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to farmers as a high-risk proposition because their profitability is affected by weather, natural disasters and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda are under-served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy farm supplies and hire workers.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to increase her working capital and to buy a large quantity of fish to sell, allowing her to increase her profits.

loans.name: Martin

texts.en:
Martin is 52 years old and married to Claris. They have three children who are one, five, and eighteen years old respectively.The first-born is in form four while the last is not yet enrolled in school. The five-year-old son is also in school. Martin owns a rental house from which he gets his daily bread.
He lives with his family in their own house that has both electricity and piped water. In addition, he operates a cyber cafe where he offers services such as printing, photocopying, web-browsing, etc.
Martin is requesting a loan so he can purchase a laminating machine and a computer.
He dreams of expanding his business and even opening more businesses in the future so as to keep his family in good living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase a laminating machine and a computer.

loans.name: Sorm

texts.en:
Sorm is 35 years old and a married woman who has been living in the Baray district of Kompong Tom province. She is diligent in her daily household work -- taking care of her children, serving food for the family, and keeping her house clean and tidy. Aside from these activities, Sorm also devotes herself to a rice farming and hog-raising business to provide the family with income. She has been in this type of business for 12 years.

Sorm wants to make improvements to her farm, so she has applied for additional capital to purchase a piece of land to expand her plot used for farming purposes. This loan will allow Sorm to go far in her business and she hopes to obtain a good harvest in the seasons to come. With the profit she will generate, she will invest in her hog-raising business to double her return and use some for her children’s education.

loans.use: to purchase a piece of land to expand her plot used for farming purposes.

loans.name: Dyne

texts.en: Dyne is 31 years old, living in a village of the Kandal Stoeng district of Cambodia. She is a married mother and works at a restaurant in the village. She has been in this business for seven years. She is able to earn approximately USD 12.33 per day from her current business. This is Dyne’s first loan with VisionFund. She is applying for a loan of USD 700.00 from VisionFund. With this loan, she is going to buy a motorbike for using in the family. In the future, she hopes to fulfill her dream of having her own business to support her family.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for using in the family.

loans.name: Nelly

texts.en:
This is Nelly, 31, a resident of GMA, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Roger, a driver, and mother to their children. She and her husband manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Nelly operates a doormat business. Her products are small rugs and larger doormats. She makes doormats out of excess textile cloth she bought from the factory. As rugs are a major part of Filipino housekeeping and cleaning, rugs are one of the most common products that can be bought, sometimes even from a peddler while you are riding in a speeding jeepney down the highway. She sells her products directly to her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 13,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of raw materials. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Nelly hopes to grow her business in the coming years and dreams of being able to give her family a good future and to send her children to college through all her hard work. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for raw materials needed in her business.

loans.name: Byambadorj

texts.en:
Mr. Byambadorj is 25 years old and lives with his wife in an old house which is in need of repair. He works as a vendor in a local store, and is requesting a loan to repair his home, which is located in the ger (or traditional Mongolian yurt) district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. He will use his loan to buy the materials he needs to replace his home's heater, old wooden floor and windows, and install insulation to reduce heat loss. In the winter, he uses a water-heated furnace to stay warm, and it costs too much and wastes a lot of water. By replacing it, he will lower his bills and improve the environment. 
  
Although Mongolia has the lowest population density in the world, it is one of the globe's most polluted countries. This is due to the long, cold winters where temperatures frequently go below -40C (-40F) even in the cities, and it frequently snows. Both homes and nomadic tents burn a lot of fuel and emit huge amounts of pollution every night from people just trying to stay warm. Extremely toxic smoke from cars is another cause of air pollution. In response to this, Credit Mongol offers Green Loans to its clients to make home improvements that reduce heat loss, improve heating systems and run cars on the natural gas. We believe that together we can decrease pollution and the harmful effects it has on the environment and on Mongolians' health.

loans.use: to buy materials to improve his home.

loans.name: Kamol

texts.en: Kamol began growing grapes two years ago. Nowadays his business is successful and is developing day by day. He grows also tomatoes, cucumbers, and corn. As he is very smart and kind-hearted, his family loves him very much. In business with Kamol is his lovely wife. She always tries to prepare tasty foods for husband. They have 4 children. Kamol and his wife try to provide them with all the modern conveniences. Kamol wants to buy aqueducts for the land on which he grows he grapes but he does not have enough money. He awaits your help and mercy.

loans.use: to buy aqueducts for the land on which he grows grapes.

loans.name: Joachim

texts.en:
Joachim is married with two children aged one-and-a-half and eighteen years. He has been a maize farmer for 4 years. His wife is also a maize farmer. He would like to get this loan to buy more seeds and support labor to get the best harvest. With the profits, he wants to renovate his house.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under-served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more seeds and support labor costs.

loans.name: Phary's Group

texts.en: Phary, aged 40 years old, is living in a rural area of Sangke district in Battambang province, Cambodia. She is divorced and has three dependent children. She has been farming on one hectare of farmland for 5 years and can earn about 66,000 KHR per day. She has been with VisionFund for two cycles and successfully paid back the past loan which has helped her have a better living condition. She is now applying for a loan of 1,400,000 KHR and she, as the group leader, will use her portion to buy fertilizers and seeds for her farmland. She hopes to earn more income from her rice farming in order to start a new business raising pigs and chicken so that she can support her family more.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and rice seeds for her farmland.
